Yankee Doodle Damn!

By Matt Siriani

The New York Yankees walk into the 2020 MLB season with a chip on their shoulder. They were knocked out of the playoffs by the Houston Astros in the ALCS in two of the last three seasons. They notched 103 wins in 2019 and had the second best offense in the MLB despite suffering 31 injuries across the entire regular season. They were also cheated out of two World Series appearances by the aforementioned Astros through the infamous sign stealing scandal that made headlines towards the tail end of last year. However, with the regular season shortened and some notable misfortunes, they aren’t off to the best of starts.

On Independence Day, the Yanks had two bumps in the road to MLB’s restart, the first game when Yankees’ right handed pitcher Masahiro Tanaka took a 112 mph liner to the head during a Yankees’ practice. Thankfully, he only suffered a mild concussion and has stated publicly that he is willing to make it back to practice and to the team as soon as he possibly could. Tanaka is coming off a season where he made his second All-Star appearance recorded 149 strikeouts and recorded a complete game shutout against the Tampa Bay Rays on June 17th, while going 11-9 in 31 starts.

The second bump that the Yankees took on the Fourth of July came when second baseman DJ Lemahieu tested positive for COVID-19. Thankfully the All-Star second baseman is asymptomatic and could more than likely be back in time for the Yanks’ opening series against the Nationals in less than two weeks. Lemahieu debuted as a Bronx Bomber last season and made a huge impact. Batting .327, hitting 26 Home Runs to go with 102 RBIs while finishing fourth in AL MVP voting.

Yankees Ace pitcher Luis Severino saw limited action last season due to a rotator cuff inflammation. The two time All-star announced in late February that he was undergoing Tommy John Surgery ruling him out for the 2020 season entirely. Before injuries came down on Severino, he was undoubtedly the Yankees’ go-to pitcher the past two years going 14-6 with a 2.98 ERA and 230 strikeouts in 2017 to go with a third place voting for the AL CY Young Award. In 2018, Severino went 19-8 with a 3.39 ERA.

The latest shot the Yankees took came today when Yankees’ star closer Aroldis Chapman tested positive for the Coronavirus and experiences mild symptoms. According to Yanks’ Manager Aaron Boone “in the event that Chapman is unable to play, relief pitcher Zack Britton would be given the closers role.” Chapman had arguably one of his best seasons yet a year ago. Recording 37 saves in 42 attempts and posting a 2.21 ERA. In 60 relief appearances, he struck out 85 batters.

While these minor setbacks are not the kind of things you wish to see as a Yankees fan, you really hope that the Yanks’ with a roster of starting talent as well as talent on the bench could pull through for their 28th ring. The Yankees begin their regular season against the Washington Nationals in Nationals park on July 23rd at 7:08 pm and could be seen on ESPN.

Patrick Mahomes gets record contract

By Matt Siriani

Over the last two seasons in the NFL, no player has been more effective and efficient than Kansas City Chiefs Quarterback Patrick Mahomes. In his first two full seasons as the starter with the Chiefs, Mahomes won an NFL MVP award in 2018 after throwing 50 touchdown passes, and this past season he captured a Super Bowl MVP award while leading the Chiefs to new heights by leading them to their first Lombardi Trophy in 50 years. But now, Mahomes also took something else to new heights, contract salaries. The 24-year old prodigy struck gold with a 10-year contract extension worth $503 million.

Mahomes concluded the third year of his five-year rookie contract with a remarkable playoff run as the Kansas City Chiefs won all three of their postseason games after being down 10 points or more in each game only to win by 10 points or more, something that has never happened before in NFL Postseason history.

This is a continuing trend that we have seen in years past with Super Bowl winning quarterbacks getting massive extensions. In 2007, former New York Giants quarterback Eli Manning in his third year as a pro was on the verge of being run out of New York. He then changed his fortunes by knocking off the undefeated New England Patriots in Super Bowl XLII, then again in 2011 earning him extensions. Joe Flacco helped lead the Baltimore Ravens to their second Super Bowl title at the conclusion of the 2012 season snatching a $120 million contract extension in the process. Tom Brady winning Super Bowl titles with the New England Patriots in 2014 and 2016 convinced the Pats that he still has something left in the tank allowing him to stay for another three seasons after Super Bowl LI.

Mahomes’ AAV (Average Annual Value) is a record shattering $50.3 million a year, breaking Seahawk’s Quarterback Russell Wilson’s AAV for his recent extension of $35 million a year.

While I think Mahomes absolutely deserves an extension, the overall number is absolutely crazy, and it could really put a lot of pressure on him to perform at a high level. We have seen Quarterbacks come crashing down to earth after hoisting the Lombardi Trophy and getting their money’s worth.

The aforementioned Joe Flacco hasn’t been the same since 2012, only reaching the playoffs once as a starter since then, battling injuries and inconsistencies. Now Flacco has bounced to the New York Jets as a backup. Eli Manning fizzled out of the NFL throughout the final 8 years of his career, eventually losing his job to Daniel Jones in week 3 of the 2019 season before ultimately retiring at season’s end.

Mahomes in two full seasons as a pro has a 108.9 Quarterback rating, won twelve games in the last two years, holds four playoff victories, has a league MVP and a Super Bowl MVP, and is arguably among the new Mount Rushmore of the best quarterbacks in the NFL today.

The Kansas City Chiefs are getting set to defend their crown in the next month and a half, but now we get ready to see how the Coronavirus as well as the pressure of being champs will play in to the Chiefs 2020 performance. The Chiefs walk into this upcoming season as the team to beat in the AFC.

This Contract extension also begs the question of how this will play into Dak Prescott’s contract situation with the Dallas Cowboys. The Cowboys have until July 15th to come up with a long-term deal with Prescott as he is playing on the franchise tag for the upcoming season.

Chief fans, I hope you are excited because Mahomes is slated to be with the Chiefs until 2031 if all goes well. The question here is will money buy the Chiefs two more Super Bowls?

The Washington Redskins might be no more

By Matt Siriani

The Washington Redskins have been an NFL franchise since 1933. The name itself has been with the team throughout 85 plus years. However, in a time where change is upon the world in more ways than one, the controversial football team name will be “thoroughly reviewed” by NFL officials and team representatives.

The cracks started to form in the 1960s and 1990s, but the first massive controversial hit came in 2013. At a symposium at the National Museum of the American Indian. The Oneida Indian Nation sponsored a series of Radio Ads to sponsor the Redskins but the ads also had a targeted message. It has been since that Native American Groups were finally being listened to after decades of being silenced.

In 2017, when the National Football League was dealing with racial issues, some commentators were speculating why there has been no action to address stereotyping of Native American people.

In Lewd of recent events that have happened in the United States, statues of racist icons have been removed, and Nike has removed all Redskins equipment and gear from there stores, and you couldn’t even get a result in search bars if you typed in the Washington Redskins.

Former Redskins owner George Preston Marshall was removed from the team’s ring of honor as it has been known for years that he didn’t want to integrate the Redskins in the early 1960’s. Anderson High School in the state of Ohio dropped the name “Redskins” from their team names and retired their mascot.

Redskins head coach Ron Rivera said “the issue is of personal importance to me, and I look forward to working closely with Dan Snyder (the Redskins current owner) during this process.” Rivera is the only Hispanic head coach in the NFL right now.

If you look at the landscape of Washington sports team names, their hockey team are the Senators, the baseball team is the Nationals, and the basketball team are the Wizards. In our nations capital, the state should follow by example and make adjustments to adhere to the needs that people of all nationalities and decent have been waiting years for. While it will feel weird seeing the Redskins under different circumstances, it will satisfy this country’s desires of equality.

In the comment section, what do you think the team’s new name should be?
